to prevent using `==` on other types

comments.body:
Not sure if we want `Case` for EnumCase. It's not a modifier in enums. 
```suggestion
        if sym.isAllOf(Case | Module) || sym.is(CaseClass) then
```
`EnumCase` how we identify singleton enum values, so `case` should be there as it is part of the definition

Case is defined as: `CASE | Has a case modifier?`

So in reality, it doesn't have a case modifier, it's more akin to match cases. I think it would be best to have it as a EnumCase, separate from just Case

Im not sure what you mean,
```scala
enum Color {
  case Red
  ...
}
```

here `Red` is defined with the `case` modifier, which is what `sym.isAllOf(EnumCase)` is checking for
Is it a modifier though? With case class it is indeed a modifier, in enum those cases are obligatory, without case they do not exist. You cannot write just "Red"

I think it is important, `case` distinguishes `Red` from being any old val (like its desugared form), which plays into things like exhaustivity checking or the "provably disjoint" check for match types. I do see we do give them the `enum` modifier also at least.
Ok, I guess if we have both it is an EnumCase kind. Makes sense!
I think it's ok to add `Case` to EnumCase, since we can tell the symbols of EnumCase by checking if there're properties : `Enum` and `Case`

comments.body: Should we have an additional kind for `inline` ? We might need to update the modifiers in semanticdb. Also, should we recognize `inline` methods as macros? @bishabosha what do you think?
I think it could be good to have a new `Inline` kind, and possibly `TransparentInline` `TransparentMacro` (due to the different semantics) but maybe they should be properties?
@tanishiking maybe let's add this together with TypeLambda and MatchType PR?

comments.body:
```suggestion
        else if sym.isOneOf(Method)) then
```
Are val/var set as methods in Scala 2?

```scala
object Foo {
  val x = 23
  var y = 47
}
```
gives with Scala 2 `metac` and `metap`:
```
Symbols:
_empty_/Foo. => final object Foo extends AnyRef { +3 decls }
_empty_/Foo.`y_=`(). => var method y_=(x$1: Int): Unit
_empty_/Foo.`y_=`().(x$1) => param x$1: Int
_empty_/Foo.x. => val method x: Int
_empty_/Foo.y(). => var method y: Int
```
So it seems it's only a method for the var.
